Book.Body:
The monoid package
Introduction This manual describes the monoid package version 4.0 for computing with transformation semigroups. monoid 4.0 is an updated version of the package with the same name for &GAP; 3; see http://schmidt.nuigalway.ie/monoid/index.html
for more information about the original monoid by Goetz Pfeiffer and Steve A. Linton, Edmund F. Robertson and Nik Ruskuc.
monoid 4.0 retains all the functionality of the original monoid package. In particular, monoid 4.0 contains more vastly more efficient methods than those available in the &GAP; library for computing orbits, calculating Green's classes, finding the size, the elements, testing membership in transformation semigroups, and testing if a semigroup satisfies a particular property; see Chapters , , and . After monoid has been loaded many of these methods are automatically used in preference to those in the library and do not need to be called explicitly by the user. The methods for Green's relations and related functions are based on those in and . Some of the methods for testing if a semigroup satisfies a certain property are described in .
The monoid package is written in &GAP; code only. However, monoid requires the orb package version 3.7 or higher to be installed.
The orb package is used to provide efficient methods for computing orbits in transformation semigroups that underpin most of the features of monoid. The monoid package can no longer be used without orb version 3.7 or higher. See
http://www-groups.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/~neunhoef/Computer/Software/Gap/orb.html
or the main &GAP; webpages for more information.
If you want to take advantage of the online help facilities in monoid, then the gapdoc package Version 1.1 or higher is also required; see
http://www.math.rwth-aachen.de/~Frank.Luebeck/GAPDoc/
for further details of how to obtain and install gapdoc.
Installing monoid
In this section we give a brief description of how to start using monoid. If you have any problems getting monoid working, then please email me directly at jdm3@st-and.ac.uk.
It is assumed that you have a working copy of &GAP; with version number 4.4.12 or higher. The most up-to-date version of &GAP; and instructions on how to install it can be obtained from the main &GAP; webpage
http://www.gap-system.org .
The following is a summary of the steps that should lead to a successful installation of monoid:
download and install the orb package version 3.7 or higher. For more details go to: http://www-groups.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/~neunhoef/Computer/Software/Gap/orb.html
download the package archive monoid4r0.tar.gz or monoid4r0.tar.bz2 from http://tinyurl.com/monoid4
unzip and untar the file, this should create a directory called monoid.
move the directory monoid into the pkg directory of your &GAP; directory (the one containing the directories lib, doc, pkg, and so on)
start &GAP; in the usual way
type LoadPackage("monoid");
Below is an example of an installation of monoid in UNIX where GAPROOT should be substituted with the main &GAP; directory (the one containing the folders `bin', `lib', and so on) in your installation of &GAP;.
> gunzip monoid4r0.tar.gz > tar -xf monoid4r0.tar > mv monoid GAPROOT/pkg > gap
[ ... ]
gap> LoadPackage("monoid"); ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Loading orb 3.7 (orb - Methods to enumerate orbits) by Juergen Mueller (http://www.math.rwth-aachen.de/~Juergen.Mueller), Max Neunhoeffer (http://www-groups.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/~neunhoef), and Felix Noeske (http://www.math.rwth-aachen.de/~Felix.Noeske). ---------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Loading monoid 4.0 (monoid: computing with transformation semigroups) by James Mitchell (http://tinyurl.com/monoid4). ---------------------------------------------------------------------- true gap>
Presuming that the above steps can be completed successfully you will be running the monoid package!
If you want to check that the package is working correctly, please see Section .
Please note: before you can used monoid you must install orb version 3.7 or higher as described above.
Testing monoid
In this section we describe how to test that monoid is working as intended. To test that monoid is installed correctly copy the following lines into &GAP;.
LoadPackage( "monoid" );; ReadTest( Filename( DirectoriesPackageLibrary( "monoid", "tst" ), "install.tst" ) );
and press return. Please note that it will take a few moments before the tests are complete.
If the output looks like the following, then it is probable that you have a fully working copy of monoid 4.0.
gap> LoadPackage( "monoid" );; LoadPackage( "monoid" );; ReadTest( Filename( DirectoriesPackageLibrary( "monoid", "tst" ), "install.tst" ) ); + install.tst 4.0 + GAP4stones: 0 gap>
If you want to perform more extensive tests, then copy the following lines into &GAP;.
LoadPackage( "monoid" );; ReadTest( Filename( DirectoriesPackageLibrary( "monoid", "tst" ), "testall.g" ) );
Please note that these tests could take a long time to finish.
If something goes wrong, then please review the instructions in Section and ensure that monoid has been properly installed. If you continue having problems, please email me at jdm3@st-and.ac.uk.
Changes from 3.1.4 to 4.0 JDM
Older versions
from 3.1.3 to 3.1.4:
MonoidOrbit, GradedOrbits, and so on now accept a transformation collection as a first argument.
If the `orb' package is available, then hash tables are used instead of plain lists when computing orbits. This dramatically increases the efficiency of these computations.
the function StrongOrbitsInForwardOrbit was introduced.
an improved method for RandomReesMatrixSemigroup has been installed so that if the third argument is a positive integer a randomly selected small group of that size is used to create the semigroup.
several other minor bugs have been fixed.
the following functions were renamed in 4.0: InfoAutos -> InfoMonoidAutos.
the following functions were removed from 4.0: GradedStrongOrbits.
from 3.1.2 to 3.1.3: the method for PreImagesRepresentative for a semigroup homomorphism by function now tests whether the homomorphism is bijective and total before trying to find preimages. Some other minor corrections were made to the documentation and webpages.

Glossary
This chapter contains a glossary of mathematical terms used throughout this manual.
Let S be a semigroup and let \Omega be a set. Then an left action of S on \Omega is just a function \Psi:S\times \Omega\to \Omega satisfying
$$\Psi(s, \Psi(t, \alpha))=\Psi(st, \alpha).$$
\Psi(s, \Psi(t, \alpha))=\Psi(st, \alpha).
Right actions are defined analogously. The (weak) orbit of \alpha \in \Omega under the action \Psi of S is the set
\text{Orb}_S(\alpha)=\{\:\beta\in\Omega\::\:(\exists s\in S)(\Psi(s, \alpha)=\beta)\:\}.
$$\text{Orb}_S(\alpha)=\{\:\beta\in\Omega\::\:(\exists s\in S)(\Psi(s, \alpha)=\beta)\:\}. $$
If S is a group, then \alpha\in \text{Orb}_S(\beta) if and only if \beta\in \text{Orb}_S(\alpha). However, if S is not a group, then it is possible that \alpha\in \text{Orb}_S(\beta) but \beta\not \in \text{Orb}_S(\alpha).
The strong orbit of \alpha\in \Omega is the set
\{\:\beta\in\Omega\::\:(\exists s,t\in S)(\Psi(s, \alpha)=\beta \wedge \Psi(t, \beta)=\alpha)\:\}.
$$\{\:\beta\in\Omega\::\:(\exists s,t\in S)(\Psi(s, \alpha)=\beta \wedge \Psi(t, \beta)=\alpha)\:\}. $$
Let S be a semigroup generated by a set of transformations \Omega on a finite set. If f\in S, then denote the image of f by \text{im}(f). The kernel of f\in S is
\text{ker}(f)=\{\:(\alpha, \beta)\::\: f(\alpha)=f(\beta)\:\}
$$\text{ker}(f)=\{\:(\alpha, \beta)\::\: f(\alpha)=f(\beta)\:\}$$
and the rank of f is simply
\text{rank}(f)=|\text{im}(f)|.
$$\text{rank}(f)=|\text{im}(f)|.$$
Let
\text{Ims}(S)=\{\:\text{im}(f)\::\: f\in S\:\}
$$\text{Ims}(S)=\{\:\text{im}(f)\::\: f\in S\:\}$$
and let
\text{Kers}(S)=\{\:\text{ker}(f)\::\: f\in S\:\}.
$$\text{Kers}(S)=\{\:\text{ker}(f)\::\: f\in S\:\}.$$

Green's Relations
This chapter contains instructions on how to use the functions for computing Green's relations and related notions for transformation semigroups and monoids that are implemented in monoid.
The theory behind these algorithms is developed in and the algorithms themselves are described in . Another reference is .
Green's relations can be calculated when monoid is loaded using the same commands that you would used when monoid is not loaded; see . For example, in &GAP; with the monoid package loaded:
gap> a:=Transformation([2,1,1,2,1]);; gap> b:=Transformation([3,4,3,4,4]);; gap> c:=Transformation([3,4,3,4,3]);; gap> d:=Transformation([4,3,3,4,4]);; gap> S:=Semigroup(a,b,c,d); <semigroup with 4 generators> gap> GreensRClasses(S); [ {Transformation( [ 2, 1, 1, 2, 1 ] )}, {Transformation( [ 1, 2, 1, 2, 2 ] )} , {Transformation( [ 1, 2, 1, 2, 1 ] )}, {Transformation( [ 2, 1, 1, 2, 2 ] )} ]
Without the monoid package loaded:
gap> a:=Transformation([2,1,1,2,1]);; gap> b:=Transformation([3,4,3,4,4]);; gap> c:=Transformation([3,4,3,4,3]);; gap> d:=Transformation([4,3,3,4,4]);; gap> S:=Semigroup(a,b,c,d); <semigroup with 4 generators> gap> GreensRClasses(S); [ {Transformation( [ 1, 2, 1, 2, 1 ] )}, {Transformation( [ 1, 2, 1, 2, 2 ] )}, {Transformation( [ 1, 2, 2, 1, 1 ] )}, {Transformation( [ 1, 2, 2, 1, 2 ] )} ]
The only noticable differences are the representatives of the classes and the order the classes appear in the list. These differences are caused by the differences in the methods for GreensRClasses in monoid and the &GAP; library.
Most of the commands in this section relate to how Green's relations are calculated in monoid. Although some of the commands might be used for other purposes, if all that is required is to calculate Green's classes, relations and so on, then this is done in the exactly the same way as described in the &GAP; manual; see .
Due to inherent difficulties with computing Green's L- and D-classes, the methods used to compute with Green's R-classes are the most efficient in monoid. Thus wherever possible it is advisable to use the commands relating to Green's R-classes rather than those relating to Green's L-classes, D-classes, or H-classes.
For small examples of semigroups, say with fewer than 40 elements, it may be more efficient to use the methods from the library than those in monoid. This stems from the fact that there are higher overheads in the methods used in monoid. In either case, with such small examples computing Green's relations does not take much time.
The methods in monoid allow the computation of individual Green's classes without the need to compute all the elements of the underlying semigroup. It is also possible to compute all the R-classes, the number of elements and test membership in a transformation semigroup without computing all the elements. This may be useful if you want to study a very large semigroup where computing all the elements of the semigroup is infeasible.

Properties of semigroups
Definitions
In this section we give the theoretical results and the corresponding &GAP; functions that can be used to determine whether a set of transformations generates a semigroup of a given type. Let S be a semigroup. Then:
S is a left zero semigroup if (\forall s,t\in S)(st=s).
S is a right zero semigroup if (\forall s,t\in S)(st=t).
S is commutative if (\forall s,t\in S)(st=ts).
S is simple if it has no proper two-sided ideals.
S is regular if (\forall s\in S)(\exists t\in S)(sts=s).
S is completely regular if every element of S lies in a subgroup.
S is an inverse semigroup if (\forall s\in S)(\exists! t\in S)(sts=s \wedge tst=t).
S is a Clifford semigroup if (\forall s\in S)(\exists t\in S)(sts=s)\wedge(\forall s, t\in S)(s^2=s\rightarrow st=ts).
S is a band if (\forall s\in S)(s^2=s).
S is a rectangular band if (\forall x,y,z\in S)(x^2=x\wedge xyz=xz).
S is a idempotent generated if it is generated by its idempotent elements.
S is an orthodox semigroup if it is regular and idempotents form a subsemigroup.
S is a zero semigroup if (\exists s\in S)(\forall t,u\in S)(tu=s).
S is a zero group if (\exists s\in S)(\forall t\in S)(st=ts=s\wedge S\setminus\{s\}\text{ is a group }).
The following results provide methods to determine if an arbitrary transformation semigroup S satisfies a particular property by considering the action of the generators of S on the underlying set, rather than S itself. For more details see .
Then the following hold:
S is a left zero semigroup if and only if \text{im}(f)=\text{im}(g) and f^2=f for all f, g\in\Omega.
S is a right zero semigroup if and only if \text{ker}(f)=\text{ker}(g) and f^2=f for all f, g\in\Omega.
S is simple if and only if \text{rank}(gf)=\text{rank}(f)=\text{rank}(g) for all f, g\in\Omega.
S is completely regular if and only if \text{rank}(fgf)=\text{rank}(gf) for all f, g\in\Omega.
S is inverse if and only if it is regular and there is a bijection \phi:\text{Kers}(S)\to\text{Ims}(S) such that if f\in S with \text{im}(f)=\phi(\text{ker}(f)), then \text{rank}(f^2)=\text{rank}(f).
S is a Clifford semigroup if and only if for all f, g\in\Omega
\text{rank}(f^2)=\text{rank}(f);
if g^n is an idempotent, then fg^n=g^nf.
It is straightforward to verify that S is a group if and only if for all f, g\in\Omega
\text{ker}(f)=\text{ker}(g);
\text{im}(f)=\text{im}(g);
\text{rank}(f)=\text{rank}(g).
